page.title: 08Banwell Education from 1765
page.content: The earliest record of a school is 1765 when the Bishop of Bath and Wells headed a subscription list with ten guineas for the upkeep of two rooms in West Street. The school must not have functioned very well as Hannah More opened a parochial school in 1791. After a promising start the school was closed down in 1799. A National School existed between 1800 and 1820. In 1824 a New National School was built on the land given by the Bishop. In 1862 the old building was exchanged for Temperance Hall in High Street. This building was officially abandoned in 1926 when the present school was opened, although it was used again between 1950 and 1960 for additional classes and school meals.
